unnormalised: Hey everyone, let's talk waste management! It’s something we all contribute to, and honestly, we could be doing a lot better, right? I saw a documentary the other day, and the piles of garbage near places like Ghazipur are just… shocking.
normalised: Hey everyone, let us talk waste management! It is something we all contribute to, and honestly, we could be doing a lot better, right? I saw a documentary the other day, and the piles of garbage near places like Ghazipur are just shocking.

unnormalised: We Indians produce a *lot* of waste, from discarded vegetable peels from aunty's kitchen to the countless plastic wrappers from that ₹10 Kurkure we grab on the go. But where does it all *go*? And what's being done about it?
normalised: We Indians produce a lot of waste, from discarded vegetable peels from aunty's kitchen to the countless plastic wrappers from that rupee ten Kurkure we grab on the go. But where does it all go? And what is being done about it?

unnormalised: I remember reading about a fantastic initiative at IIT Delhi focusing on biodegradable plastics and waste-to-energy projects. That's the kind of innovation we need! Imagine if every municipality in India adopted similar technologies!
normalised: I remember reading about a fantastic initiative at I I T Delhi focusing on biodegradable plastics and waste-to-energy projects. That is the kind of innovation we need! Imagine if every municipality in India adopted similar technologies!

unnormalised: But technology is only part of the solution. We need to change our mindset too. Remember the movie "Toilet: Ek Prem Katha"? It highlighted sanitation issues, but it also touched upon waste management indirectly. It’s about responsibility, both individual and collective.
normalised: But technology is only part of the solution. We need to change our mindset too. Remember the movie "Toilet: Ek Prem Katha"? It highlighted sanitation issues, but it also touched upon waste management indirectly. It is about responsibility, both individual and collective.

unnormalised: Simple things like segregating waste at home, using reusable bags when you visit the local sabzi mandi in Karol Bagh, and composting kitchen scraps can make a huge difference. What are some small changes you've made in your daily routine to reduce waste? Share your tips below! Let's learn from each other. Also, has anyone used local government waste pickup services in their area? How was the experience?
